Award.AwardTitle: Conformationally Controllable Amphiphiles and Their Applications in Sensor Design
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support of this award from the Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program Professor Yan Zhao will explore conformational control, which is at the heart of biology. The binding and catalytic functions of many protein receptors and enzymes are regulated through their controlled conformational changes. Therefore, being able to guide the conformational behavior of organic molecules is highly important to both fundamental and applied chemistry and biology. This research focuses on the bioinspired utilization of solvophobic interactions for conformational control of amphiphilic foldamers. The overall objective is to synthesize amphiphilic foldamers with well controlled folding/unfolding behavior and demonstrate their applications as a novel class of molecular sensors. The proposed foldamers can be synthesized from readily available materials. They have highly unusual properties including large (> 1 nm) hydrophilic internal cavity, controllable distribution of internal functional groups, nanometer-sized dimension, and tunable conformational stability. The foldamers proposed in this application will be converted into sensors that can detect metal ions, temperature changes, or small-molecule analytes.
The proposed research is expected to have several broad impacts in chemical and pharmaceutical industries. For example, the proposed molecular sensors potentially can be used to detect molecular species including drug or drug metabolites, or heavy metals in environmental applications. In addition, the proposed biomimetic chemistry provides excellent trainings to graduate and undergraduate students involved in the research. Students will develop important skills in designing synthetic structures to mimic biological molecules. They will also be exposed to a wide range of research fields due to the interdisciplinary nature of the proposed work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conformational control is at the heart of biology. Despite decades of efforts, biologists are unable to design well-folded protein structures from the scratch. This reflects our poor understanding of the conformational control problem. Our research seeks to design conformationally controllable amphiphilic foldamers mimicking proteins in structures and functions. The results will advance our understanding of the driving forces behind the conformational changes of proteins. The solvophobically driven folding enables us to improve our knowledge in solvophobic (i.e., hydrophobic) interactions, which represent the major driving force for protein folding in water.

This project focuses on the bioinspired utilization of solvophobic interactions for conformational control of amphiphilic foldamers. The overall objective is to synthesize amphiphilic foldamers with well controlled folding/unfolding behavior and demonstrate their applications as a novel class of molecular sensors. The foldamers are synthesized from readily available materials. They have highly unusual properties including large (> 1 nm) hydrophilic internal cavity, controllable distribution of internal functional groups, nanometer-sized dimension, and tunable conformational stability. Their conformational behavior is studied by a range of techniques including UV spectroscopy, fluorescence energy transfer, fluorescence quenching, and NMR spectroscopy. 

The materials developed have commercial potentials as sensory and controlled-release devices. We recently reported foldamers whose binding affinity toward mercury ions could be tuned over five orders of magnitude by simple solvent changes. These materials potentially may be used as reusable absorbents for toxic wastes. Once the capacity is reached, the materials may be regenerated and reused. The concept may be applied also to controlled-release of drug molecules.      

The proposed research is expected to have several broad impacts in chemical and pharmaceutical industries. For example, the design principles can be used as a platform to create other useful materials such as thermo-responsive “smart” coatings. The proposed molecular sensors potentially can be used to detect molecular species including drug or drug metabolites, or heavy metals in environmental applications.

The research is used to train students as future scientists. The multidisciplinary research requires the students to acquire a broad range of skills including biomimetic design of molecules, multistep synthesis, structural characterization, spectroscopic study, curve fitting, kinetic studies, and handling of organic- and water-soluble materials. The training exposes the students to cutting-edge physical organic chemistry, biology, and materials science.

The PI includes the biomimetic research in his graduate and undergraduate classes. He teaches Physical Organic Chemistry to graduate students and uses the conformational characterization of the foldamers to illustrate how multiple spectroscopic methods are used to reveal the folding mechanism. In the undergraduate organic class (for non-science majors), he illustrates how conformation (which might be abstract and far from real life to many students) can be used as a rational tool to design 'smart' molecules capable of molecular recognition (in sensory applications), temperature detection (as 'molecular thermometers'), and catalysis (in enzymatic mimicry). He helps non-science students understand how chemists learn from nature and develop useful materials for technological and biomedical applications.
